papers.title: Deep Learning Based Code Generation Methods: A Literature Review
papers.authors: Zezhou Yang,Sirong Chen,Cuiyun Gao,Zhenhao Li,Ge Li,Rongcong Lv
papers.summary: The existing research results of each category of methods are systematically reviewed, summarized and commented and the overall literature review is summarized and provides a prospect on future research directions worthy of attention.

papers.title: R-U-SURE? Uncertainty-Aware Code Suggestions By Maximizing Utility Across Random User Intents
papers.authors: Daniel D. Johnson,Daniel Tarlow,Christian J. Walder
papers.summary: This work proposes Randomized Utility-driven Synthesis of Uncertain REgions (R-U-SURE), an approach for building uncertainty-aware suggestions based on a decision-theoretic model of goal-conditioned utility, using random samples from a generative model as a proxy for the unobserved possible intents of the end user.

papers.title: Learning Performance-Improving Code Edits
papers.authors: Aman Madaan,Alex Shypula,Uri Alon,Milad Hashemi,Parthasarathy Ranganathan,Yiming Yang,Graham Neubig,A. Yazdanbakhsh
papers.summary: This paper investigates the ability of large language models (LLMs) to suggest functionally correct, performance improving code edits, and hypothesizes that language models can suggest such edits in ways that would be impractical for static analysis alone.

papers.title: DocPrompting: Generating Code by Retrieving the Docs
papers.authors: Shuyan Zhou,Uri Alon,Frank F. Xu,Zhiruo Wang,Zhengbao Jiang,Graham Neubig
papers.summary: DocPrompting is introduced: a natural-language-to-code generation approach that explicitly leverages documentation by retrieving the relevant documentation pieces given an NL intent, and generating code based on the NL intent and the retrieved documentation.

papers.title: Piloting Copilot and Codex: Hot Temperature, Cold Prompts, or Black Magic?
papers.authors: Jean-Baptiste DÃ¶derlein,M. Acher,D. Khelladi,B. Combemale
papers.summary: The results showed that varying the input parameters can significantly improve the performance of language models, however, there is a tight dependency when varying the temperature, the prompt and the number of generated solutions, making potentially hard for developers to properly control the parameters to obtain an optimal result.

papers.title: LEVER: Learning to Verify Language-to-Code Generation with Execution
papers.authors: Ansong Ni,Srini Iyer,Dragomir R. Radev,V. Stoyanov,Wen-tau Yih,Sida I. Wang,Xi Victoria Lin
papers.summary: This work proposes LEVER, a simple approach to improve language-to-code generation by learning to verify the generated programs with their execution results, which consistently improves over the base CodeLMs and achieves new state-of-the-art results on all of them.

papers.title: Automated Repair of Code from Language Models
papers.authors: Zhiyu Fan,Xiang Gao,M. Mirchev,Abhik Roychoudhury,Shin Hwei Tan
papers.summary: The study revealed that automatically generated code shares common programming mistakes with human-crafted solutions, indicating APR techniques may have potential to auto-generated code, and given bug location information provided by a statistical fault localization approach, Codex edit mode is similar to or better than existing Java repair tools TBar and Recoder in correcting incorrect solutions.

papers.title: Is GitHub's Copilot as Bad As Humans at Introducing Vulnerabilities in Code?
papers.authors: Owura Asare,M. Nagappan,Nirmal Asokan
papers.summary: A comparative empirical analysis of Copilot-generated code from a security perspective concludes that Copilot is not as bad as human developers at introducing vulnerabilities in code.

papers.title: Automated Repair of Programs from Large Language Models
papers.authors: Zhiyu Fan,Xiang Gao,M. Mirchev,Abhik Roychoudhury,Shin Hwei Tan
papers.summary: The study revealed that automatically generated code shares common programming mistakes with human-crafted solutions, indicating APR techniques may have potential to auto-generated code, and given bug location information provided by a statistical fault localization approach, Codex edit mode is similar to or better than existing Java repair tools TBar and Recoder in correcting incorrect solutions.

papers.title: Diverse Title Generation for Stack Overflow Posts with Multiple Sampling Enhanced Transformer
papers.authors: Fengji Zhang,Jin Liu,Yao Wan,Xiao Yu,Xiao Liu,J. Keung
papers.summary: This work proposes M$_3$NSCT5, a novel approach to automatically generate multiple post titles from the given code snippets, using the maximal marginal multiple nucleus sampling strategy to generate multiple high-quality and diverse title candidates at a time for the developers to choose from.

papers.title: Controlling Large Language Models to Generate Secure and Vulnerable Code
papers.authors: Jingxuan He,Martin T. Vechev

papers.title: Don't Complete It! Preventing Unhelpful Code Completion for Productive and Sustainable Neural Code Completion Systems
papers.authors: Zhensu Sun,Xiaoning Du,Fu Song,Shangwen Wang,Mingze Ni,Li Li
papers.summary: An early-rejection mechanism to turn down low-return prompts by foretelling the code completion qualities without sending them to the codepletion system is proposed and a lightweight Transformer-based estimator is proposed to demonstrate the feasibility of the mechanism.

papers.title: A Scalable and Extensible Approach to Benchmarking NL2Code for 18 Programming Languages
papers.authors: Federico Cassano,John Gouwar,Daniel Nguyen,S. Nguyen,Luna Phipps-Costin,Donald Pinckney,Ming-Ho Yee,Yangtian Zi,Carolyn Jane Anderson,Molly Q. Feldman,Arjun Guha,M. Greenberg,Abhinav Jangda
papers.summary: It is shown that on several languages, Codex matches and even exceeds its performance on Python, and a general approach is described for easily adding support for new benchmarks and languages to MultiPL-E, the first multi-language parallel benchmark for natural-language-to-code-generation.

papers.title: I Speak, You Verify: Toward Trustworthy Neural Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Darren Key,Wen-Ding Li,Kevin Ellis
papers.summary: An approach for improving the trustworthiness and overall accuracy of program synthesizers based on large language models for source code by analyzing the agreement between programs and predicates to judge both which program is most likely to be correct and whether the language model is able to solve the programming problem in the first place.

papers.title: Explicit Knowledge Transfer for Weakly-Supervised Code Generation
papers.authors: Zhangir Azerbayev,Ansong Ni,Hailey Schoelkopf,Dragomir R. Radev
papers.summary: This paper proposes explicit knowledge transfer (EKT), which uses the few-shot capabilities of a teacher LLM to create NL-code pairs that are filter for correctness and fine-tune the student on, and finds that EKT not only yields better performance than training with expert iteration, but also outperforms knowledge distillation, another form of knowledge transfer.

papers.title: Recommending Root-Cause and Mitigation Steps for Cloud Incidents using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Toufique Ahmed,Supriyo Ghosh,Chetan Bansal,T. Zimmermann,Xuchao Zhang,S. Rajmohan
papers.summary: This work does the first large-scale study to evaluate the effectiveness of GPT-3.x models for helping engineers root cause and mitigate production incidents and compares several large language models in zero-shot, fine-tuned and multi-task setting using semantic and lexical metrics.

papers.title: Execution-based Code Generation using Deep Reinforcement Learning
papers.authors: Parshin Shojaee,Aneesh Jain,S. Tipirneni,C. Reddy
papers.summary: PPOCoder is a new framework for code generation that combines pretrained PL models with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) deep reinforcement learning and employs execution feedback as the external source of knowledge into the model optimization, which is transferable across different code generation tasks and PLs.

papers.title: Fooling MOSS Detection with Pretrained Language Models
papers.venue: International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management
papers.authors: Stella Rose Biderman,Edward Raff
papers.summary: It is found that a student using GPT-J can complete introductory level programming assignments without triggering suspicion from MOSS, a widely used software similarity and plagiarism detection tool.

papers.title: CodeGen: An Open Large Language Model for Code with Multi-Turn Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Erik Nijkamp,Bo Pang,Hiroaki Hayashi,Lifu Tu,Haiquan Wang,Yingbo Zhou,S. Savarese,Caiming Xiong
papers.summary: This work trains and releases a family of large language models up to 16.1B parameters, called CODEGEN, on natural language and programming language data, and open source the training library JAXFORMER and model checkpoints, and investigates the multi-step paradigm for program synthesis.

papers.title: Learning Math Reasoning from Self-Sampled Correct and Partially-Correct Solutions
papers.authors: Ansong Ni,J. Inala,Chenglong Wang,Oleksandr Polozov,Christopher Meek,Dragomir R. Radev,Jianfeng Gao
papers.summary: It is shown that the use of self-sampled correct and partially-correct solutions can benefit learning and help guide the sampling process, leading to more efficient exploration of the solution space and the effectiveness of the method is shown.

papers.title: Lost at C: A User Study on the Security Implications of Large Language Model Code Assistants
papers.authors: Gustavo Sandoval,H. Pearce,Teo Nys,R. Karri,S. Garg,Brendan Dolan-Gavitt
papers.summary: A security-driven user study to assess code written by student programmers when assisted by LLMs and indicates that the security impact in this setting is small: AI-assisted users produce critical security bugs at a rate no greater than 10% more than the control.

papers.title: Enabling Transformers to Understand Low-Level Programs
papers.venue: IEEE Conference on High Performance Extreme Computing
papers.authors: Zifan Carl Guo,William S. Moses
papers.summary: This work applies transfer learning to low-level (LLVM) programs and study how low- level programs can be made more amenable to Transformer models through various techniques, including preprocessing, infix/prefix operators, and information deduplication.

papers.title: A Survey of Deep Learning for Mathematical Reasoning
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Liang Qiu,Wenhao Yu,S. Welleck,Kai-Wei Chang
papers.summary: This survey paper reviews the key tasks, datasets, and methods at the intersec-tion of mathematical reasoning and deep learning over the past decade, and evaluates existing benchmarks and methods and discusses future research directions.

papers.title: The Premature Obituary of Programming
papers.authors: D. Yellin
papers.summary: Why deep learning will not replace programming and why deep learning should not be considered as a programming language.

papers.title: Adaptive Test Generation Using a Large Language Model
papers.authors: Max SchÃ¤fer,Sarah Nadi,A. Eghbali,F. Tip
papers.summary: TestPilot uses Codex, an off-the-shelf LLM, to automatically generate unit tests for a given program without requiring additional training or few-shot learning on examples of existing tests, and finds that TestPilot does not generate memorized tests.

papers.title: Security Implications of Large Language Model Code Assistants: A User Study
papers.authors: Gustavo Sandoval,H. Pearce,Teo Nys,R. Karri,Brendan Dolan-Gavitt,S. Garg
papers.summary: A security-driven user study to assess code written by student programmers when assisted by LLMs and indicates that the security impact in this setting is small: AI-assisted users produce critical security bugs at a rate no greater than 10% more than the control.

papers.title: Large Language Models are Few-shot Testers: Exploring LLM-based General Bug Reproduction
papers.authors: Sungmin Kang,Juyeon Yoon,Shin Yoo
papers.summary: Results show L IBRO has the potential to enhance developerency by automatically generating tests from bug reports, and is proposed as a framework that uses Large Language Models (LLMs), which have been shown to be capable of performing code-related tasks.

papers.title: ContraGen: Effective Contrastive Learning For Causal Language Model
papers.authors: Nihal Jain,Dejiao Zhang,Wasi Uddin Ahmad,Zijian Wang,Feng Nan,Xiaopeng Li,M. Tan,Ramesh Nallapati,Baishakhi Ray,Parminder Bhatia,Xiaofei Ma,Bing Xiang
papers.summary: It is shown that C ONTRA G EN can effectively enhance both uniformity and discrimination of the representations and lead to the desired improvement on various language understanding tasks where discriminative representations are crucial for attaining good performance.

papers.title: How Readable is Model-generated Code? Examining Readability and Visual Inspection of GitHub Copilot
papers.venue: 37th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
papers.authors: Naser Al Madi
papers.summary: The results suggest that model generated code is comparable in complexity and readability to code written by human pair programmers, and eye tracking data suggests, to a statistically significant level, that programmers direct less visual attention to model generate code.

papers.title: Language Models of Code are Few-Shot Commonsense Learners
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Aman Madaan,Shuyan Zhou,Uri Alon,Yiming Yang,Graham Neubig
papers.summary: This paper shows that when this task is frame as code generation tasks, pre-trained LMs of code are better structured commonsense reasoners than L Ms of natural language, even when the downstream task does not involve source code at all.

papers.title: ObSynth: An Interactive Synthesis System for Generating Object Models from Natural Language Specifications
papers.authors: Alex Gu,Tamara Mitrovska,D. VÃ©lez,Jacob Andreas,Armando Solar-Lezama
papers.summary: ObSynth is introduced, an interactive system leveraging the domain knowledge em-bedded in large language models (LLMs) to help users design object models from high level natural language prompts, showing that it often synthesizes objects, methods, and methods users might have otherwise omitted.

papers.title: Large Language Models Are Human-Level Prompt Engineers
papers.authors: Yongchao Zhou,Andrei Ioan Muresanu,Ziwen Han,Keiran Paster,Silviu Pitis,Harris Chan,Jimmy Ba
papers.summary: It is shown that APE-engineered prompts can be applied to steer models toward truthfulness and/or informativeness, as well as to improve few-shot learning performance by simply prepending them to standard in-context learning prompts.

papers.title: SecurityEval dataset: mining vulnerability examples to evaluate machine learning-based code generation techniques
papers.authors: Mohammed Latif Siddiq,msiddiq
papers.summary: SecurityEval, an evaluation dataset that contains 130 samples for 75 vulnerability types, which are mapped to the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) and demonstrated using one open-source and one closed-source code generation model to evaluate.

papers.title: Programming by Example and Text-to-Code Translation for Conversational Code Generation
papers.authors: Eli Whitehouse,William Gerard,Yauhen Klimovich,Marc Franco-Salvador
papers.summary: Modular Programs for Text-guided Hierarchical Synthesis (MPaTHS), a method for integrating Programming by Example and text-to-code systems which uses an accessible natural language interface for synthesizing general programs, is proposed.

papers.title: Systematic Literature Review on Solving Competitive Programming Problem with Artificial Intelligence (AI)
papers.venue: 2022 1st International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
papers.authors: Francis Alexander,Edwin Ario Abdiwijaya,Felix Pherry,A. A. Gunawan,Anderies
papers.summary: It can be concluded that the code auto-completion and code-generation tools that are available now still do not meet the necessary benchmark which is solving CP tasks, and AI still has a long way to go before competing at the highest level of CP.

papers.title: Program Repair
papers.authors: Xiang Gao,Yannic Noller,Abhik Roychoudhury
papers.summary: Keeping intermediate rules, instead of producing the most generalized rule by generalizing all concrete transformations, enables us to apply the most suitable rule to transform a given code.

papers.title: Codex Hacks HackerRank: Memorization Issues and a Framework for Code Synthesis Evaluation
papers.authors: Anjan Karmakar,Julian Aron Prenner,Marco D'Ambros,R. Robbes
papers.summary: This work evaluates the code synthesis capabilities of the Codex model based on a set of 115 Python problem statements from a popular competitive programming portal: HackerRank, and proposes a framework for code-synthesis evaluation using variations of problem statements based on mutations.

papers.title: Don't Generate, Discriminate: A Proposal for Grounding Language Models to Real-World Environments
papers.authors: Yu Gu,Xiang Deng,Yu Su
papers.summary: Pangu is proposed, a generic framework for grounded language understanding that capitalizes on the discriminative ability of LMs instead of their generative ability, and enables, for the first time, effective few-shot in-context learning for KBQA with large LMs such as Codex.

papers.title: Fuzzing Deep-Learning Libraries via Large Language Models
papers.authors: Yinlin Deng,Chun Xia,Haoran Peng,Chenyuan Yang,Lingming Zhang
papers.summary: LLMFuzz is the first automated approach to directly leveraging Large Pre-trained Language Models (LLMs) to generate input programs for fuzzing DL libraries, and is able to detect 65 bugs, with 41 already confirmed as previously unknown bugs.

papers.title: Conversing with Copilot: Exploring Prompt Engineering for Solving CS1 Problems Using Natural Language
papers.venue: Proceedings of the 54th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education V. 1
papers.authors: Paul Denny,Viraj Kumar,Nasser Giacaman
papers.summary: Evaluating the performance of Copilot on a publicly available dataset of 166 programming problems finds that it successfully solves around half of these problems on its very first attempt, and that it solves 60% of the remaining problems using only natural language changes to the problem description.

papers.title: Generating High-Precision Feedback for Programming Syntax Errors using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Tung Phung,J. Cambronero,Sumit Gulwani,Tobias Kohn,R. Majumdar,A. Singla,Gustavo Soares
papers.summary: The key idea behind PyFiXV is to use a novel run-time validation mechanism to decide whether the generated feedback is suitable for sharing with the student; notably, this validation mechanism also provides a precision knob to educators.

papers.title: Beware of the Unexpected: Bimodal Taint Analysis
papers.authors: Yiu Wai Chow,Max SchÃ¤fer,Michael Pradel
papers.summary: Fluffy is presented, a bimodal taint analysis that combines static analysis, which reasons about data flow, with machine learning, which probabilistically determines which flows are potentially problematic.

papers.title: SkCoder: A Sketch-based Approach for Automatic Code Generation
papers.authors: Jia Li,Yongming Li,Ge Li,Zhi Jin,Yiyang Hao,Xing Hu
papers.summary: This paper proposes a sketch-based code generation approach named SkCoder to mimic developers' code reuse behavior, which retrieves a similar code snippet, extracts relevant parts as a code sketch, and edits the sketch into the desired code.

papers.title: Generation Probabilities Are Not Enough: Exploring the Effectiveness of Uncertainty Highlighting in AI-Powered Code Completions
papers.authors: Helena Vasconcelos,Gagan Bansal,Adam Fourney,Q. Liao,Jennifer Wortman Vaughan
papers.summary: The question of whether conveying information about uncertainty enables programmers to more quickly and accurately produce code when collaborating with an AI-powered code completion tool, and if so, what measure of uncertainty best fits programmers' needs is explored.

papers.title: The Programmer's Assistant: Conversational Interaction with a Large Language Model for Software Development
papers.authors: Steven I. Ross,Fernando Martinez,Stephanie Houde,Michael J. Muller,Justin D. Weisz
papers.summary: This work developed a prototype system -- the Programmer's Assistant -- in order to explore the utility of conversational interactions grounded in code, as well as software engineers' receptiveness to the idea of conversing with, rather than invoking, a code-fluent LLM.

papers.title: LLaMA: Open and Efficient Foundation Language Models
papers.authors: Hugo Touvron,Thibaut Lavril,Gautier Izacard,Xavier Martinet,Marie-Anne Lachaux,TimothÃ©e Lacroix,Baptiste RoziÃ¨re,Naman Goyal,Eric Hambro,Faisal Azhar,Aur'elien Rodriguez,Armand Joulin,Edouard Grave,Guillaume Lample
papers.summary: LLaMA, a collection of foundation language models ranging from 7B to 65B parameters, is introduced and it is shown that it is possible to train state-of-the-art models using publicly available datasets exclusively, without resorting to proprietary and inaccessible datasets.

papers.title: CodeRetriever: Large-scale Contrastive Pre-training for Code Search
papers.authors: Xiaonan Li,Yeyun Gong,Yelong Shen,Xipeng Qiu,Hang Zhang,Bolun Yao,Weizhen Qi,Daxin Jiang,Weizhu Chen,Nan Duan

papers.title: Who Evaluates the Evaluators? On Automatic Metrics for Assessing AI-based Offensive Code Generators
papers.authors: Cristina Improta,Pietro Liguori,R. Natella,B. Cukic,Domenico Cotroneo
papers.summary: This work analyzes a large set of output similarity metrics on offensive code generators and applies the metrics on two state-of-the-art NMT models using two datasets containing offensive assembly and Python code with their descriptions in the English language.

papers.title: A Survey of Learning-based Automated Program Repair
papers.authors: Quanjun Zhang,Chunrong Fang,Yuxiang Ma,Weisong Sun,Zhenyu Chen
papers.summary: This work presents a meta-modelling system that automates the very labor-intensive and therefore time-heavy and therefore expensive and expensive process of manually cataloging and cataloging individual neurons in the brain.

papers.title: Towards a Mathematics Formalisation Assistant using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Ayush Agrawal,Siddhartha Gadgil,Navin Goyal,Ashvni Narayanan,Anand Tadipatri
papers.summary: The abilities of a large language model (Codex) to help with formalisation in the Lean theorem prover are explored, finding that with careful inputdependent prompt selection and postprocessing, Codex is able to formalise short mathematical statements at undergrad level with nearly 75% accuracy for 120 theorem statements.

papers.title: Language Model Crossover: Variation through Few-Shot Prompting
papers.authors: Elliot Meyerson,M. Nelson,Herbie Bradley,Arash Moradi,Amy K. Hoover,J. Lehman
papers.summary: The conclusion is that language model crossover is a promising method for evolving genomes representable as text through evolving binary bit-strings, sentences, equations, text-to-image prompts, and Python code.

papers.title: C ODEX HACKS H ACKER R ANK : B ENEFITS AND R ISKS OF L ARGE -S CALE S OURCE C ODE M ODELS
papers.summary: These studies evaluate Codex on code synthesis, similar to the approach, but their evaluation efforts remain limited to math problems.

papers.title: G ENERATING S EQUENCES BY L EARNING TO [S ELF -]C ORRECT
Dataset of Student Solutions to Algorithm and Data Structure Programming Assignments
papers.venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation
papers.authors: Fynn Petersen-Frey,Marcus Soll,Louis Kobras,Melf Johannsen,Peter Kling,Chris Biemann
papers.summary: This paper presents a dataset containing source code solutions to algorithmic programming exercises solved by hundreds of Bachelor-level students at the University of Hamburg, and plans to extend the dataset with tasks and solutions from upcoming courses.

papers.title: BF++: a language for general-purpose program synthesis
papers.authors: Vadim Liventsev,A. Harma,M. Petkovi'c
papers.summary: A new programming language, BF ++ is proposed, designed speciï¬cally for automatic programming of agents in a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) setting and apply neural program synthesis to solve standard OpenAI Gym benchmarks.

papers.title: Show Your Work: Scratchpads for Intermediate Computation with Language Models
papers.authors: Maxwell Nye,Anders Andreassen,Guy Gur-Ari,H. Michalewski,Jacob Austin,David Bieber,David Dohan,Aitor Lewkowycz,Maarten Bosma,D. Luan,Charles Sutton,Augustus Odena
papers.summary: Surprisingly, large pre-trained language models are able to perform complex multistep computationsâeven in the few-shot regimeâwhen asked to perform the operation âstep by stepâ, showing the results of intermediate computations.

papers.title: Examining Zero-Shot Vulnerability Repair with Large Language Models
papers.authors: H. Pearce,B. Tan,Baleegh Ahmad,R. Karri,Brendan Dolan-Gavitt
papers.summary: This work examines the use of large language models for code (such as OpenAIâs Codex and AI21's Jurassic J-1) for zero-shot vulnerability repair, and investigates challenges in the design of prompts that coax LLMs into generating repaired versions of insecure code.

papers.title: C OMPOSITIONAL G ENERALIZATION AND D ECOMPOSITION IN N EURAL P ROGRAM S YNTHESIS
papers.summary: A suite of generalization tasks, which measure different types of compositional generalization that are desirable for program synthesis and are particularly difï¬cult for current sequence to sequence models, are proposed.

papers.title: P ATCH G ENERATION WITH L ANGUAGE M ODELS : F EASIBILITY AND S CALING B EHAVIOR
papers.authors: Sophia Kolak,Ruben Martins,Claire Le Goues,V. Hellendoorn
papers.summary: This work highlights a noticeable correlation of model size with test-passing accuracy and patch ranking quality, and the propensity for especially the largest models to generate candidate patches that closely resemble (if not exactly match), the original developer patch.

papers.title: Open-ended Knowledge Tracing for Computer Science Education
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Naiming Liu,Zichao Wang
papers.summary: An initial solution to the OKT problem is developed, a student knowledge-guided code generation approach that combines program synthesis methods using language models with student knowledge tracing methods and a series of quantitative and qualitative experiments on a real-world student code dataset to validate and demonstrate the promise of OKT.

papers.title: Source Code Generation from Descriptions in a Natural Language
papers.authors: Bc. Jan PaÅ¡ek
papers.summary: This work introduces CodeFormer, a Python source code generator pretrained on a massive GitHub crawl consisting of 230M Python functions, and releases the resulting model, built on BART architecture, which generates Python functions based on descriptions in English.

papers.title: Leveraging Automated Unit Tests for Unsupervised Code Translation
papers.authors: Baptiste RoziÃ¨re,J Zhang,FranÃ§ois Charton,M. Harman,Gabriel Synnaeve,Guillaume Lample
papers.summary: This work proposes to leverage an automated unit-testing system to filter out invalid translations, thereby creating a fully tested parallel corpus, and finds that fine-tuning an unsupervised model with this filtered data set significantly reduces the noise in the translations so-generated, comfortably outperforming the state of the art for all language pairs studied.

papers.title: Large Language Models are not Models of Natural Language: they are Corpus Models.
papers.authors: C. Veres
papers.summary: It is argued that the term language model is misleading because deep learning models are not theoretical models of language and proposed the adoption of corpus model instead, which better reflects the genesis and contents of the model.

papers.title: Open-Ended Knowledge Tracing
papers.authors: Naiming Liu,Zichao Wang,Richard Baraniuk,Andrew S. Lan
papers.summary: This paper develops an initial solution to the OKT problem, a student knowledge-guided code generation approach that combines program synthesis methods using language models with student knowledge tracing methods and conducts a series of quantitative and qualitative experiments on a real-world student code dataset to validate OKT and demonstrate its promise in educational applications.

papers.title: The impact of lexical and grammatical processing on generating code from natural language
papers.authors: Nathanael Beau,Benoit Crabb'e
papers.summary: The paper highlights the importance of the lexical substitution component in the current natural language to code systems with a state-of-the-art architecture that relies on BERT encoder and a grammar-based decoder for which a formalization is provided.

papers.title: A Conversational Paradigm for Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Erik Nijkamp,Bo Pang,Hiroaki Hayashi,Lifu Tu,Haiquan Wang,Yingbo Zhou,S. Savarese,Caiming Xiong
papers.summary: This work proposes and trains C ODE G EN, an interactive code generation model for program synthesis, and suggests that the capacity of conversational program synthesis scales as a function of the model size and data size.

papers.title: PaLM: Scaling Language Modeling with Pathways
papers.authors: Aakanksha Chowdhery,Sharan Narang,Jacob Devlin,Maarten Bosma,Gaurav Mishra,Adam Roberts,P. Barham,Hyung Won Chung,Charles Sutton,Sebastian Gehrmann,Parker Schuh,Kensen Shi,Sasha Tsvyashchenko,Joshua Maynez,Abhishek Rao,Parker Barnes,Yi Tay,Noam M. Shazeer,Vinodkumar Prabhakaran,Emily Reif,Nan Du,B. Hutchinson,Reiner Pope,James Bradbury,Jacob Austin,M. Isard,Guy Gur-Ari,Pengcheng Yin,Toju Duke,Anselm Levskaya,S. Ghemawat,Sunipa Dev,H. Michalewski,Xavier GarcÃ­a,Vedant Misra,Kevin Robinson,L. Fedus,Denny Zhou,Daphne Ippolito,D. Luan,Hyeontaek Lim,Barret Zoph,A. Spiridonov,Ryan Sepassi,David Dohan,Shivani Agrawal,Mark Omernick,Andrew M. Dai,T. S. Pillai,Marie Pellat,Aitor Lewkowycz,Erica Moreira,Rewon Child,Oleksandr Polozov,Katherine Lee,Zongwei Zhou,Xuezhi Wang,Brennan Saeta,Mark DÃ­az,Orhan Firat,Michele Catasta,Jason Wei,K. Meier-Hellstern,D. Eck,J. Dean,Slav Petrov,Noah Fiedel
papers.summary: A 540-billion parameter, densely activated, Transformer language model, which is called PaLM achieves breakthrough performance, outperforming the state-of-the-art on a suite of multi-step reasoning tasks, and outperforming average human performance on the recently released BIG-bench benchmark.

papers.title: Compositional Generalization and Decomposition in Neural Program Synthesis
papers.authors: Kensen Shi,Joey Hong,M. Zaheer,Pengcheng Yin,Charles Sutton
papers.summary: A suite of generalization tasks, which measure different types of compositional generalization that are desirable for program synthesis and are particularly difï¬cult for current sequence to sequence models, are proposed.

papers.title: Passport: Improving Automated Formal Verification Using Identifiers
papers.authors: Alex Sanchez-Stern,E. First,Timothy Zhou,Zhanna Kaufman,Yuriy Brun,T. Ringer
papers.summary: Passport is a fully-automated proof-synthesis tool that encodes one additional aspect of that rich proof data: identifiers, suggesting that modeling identifiers can play a significant role in improving proof synthesis, leading to higher-quality software.

papers.title: Self-Programming Artificial Intelligence Using Code-Generating Language Models
papers.authors: Alex Sheng,Shankar Padmanabhan
papers.summary: It is empirically show that a self-programming AI implemented using a code generation model can successfully modify its own source code to improve performance and program sub-models to perform auxiliary tasks.

papers.title: Neural language models for network configuration: Opportunities and reality check
papers.authors: Zied Ben-Houidi,Dario Rossi
papers.summary: Recent advances in deep learning applied to programming languages, for the purpose of code verification, synthesis and translation are surveyed, in particularly, their training requirements and expected performance are reviewed, and qualitatively assess whether similar techniques can benefit corresponding use-cases in networking.

papers.title: NaturalProver: Grounded Mathematical Proof Generation with Language Models
papers.authors: S. Welleck,Jiacheng Liu,Ximing Lu,Hannaneh Hajishirzi,Yejin Choi
papers.summary: N ATURAL P ROVER is capable of proving some theorems that require short (2-6 step) proofs, and providing next-step suggestions that are rated as correct and useful over 40% of the time, which is to the authors' knowledge the first demonstration of these capabilities using neural language models.

papers.title: Automatic Generation of Programming Exercises and Code Explanations Using Large Language Models
papers.authors: Sami Sarsa,Paul Denny,Arto Hellas,Juho Leinonen
papers.summary: The analysis suggests that there is significant value in massive generative machine learning models as a tool for instructors, although there remains a need for some oversight to ensure the quality of the generated content before it is delivered to students.

papers.title: FixEval: Execution-based Evaluation of Program Fixes for Competitive Programming Problems
papers.authors: Md. Mahim Anjum Haque,W. Ahmad,Ismini Lourentzou,Chris Brown
papers.summary: This work introduces F IX E VAL, a benchmark comprising of buggy code submissions to competitive programming problems and their respective ï¬xes, and believes it provides a step towards real-world automatic bugï¬xing and model-generated code evaluation.

papers.title: Solving Quantitative Reasoning Problems with Language Models
papers.authors: Aitor Lewkowycz,Anders Andreassen,David Dohan,Ethan Dyer,H. Michalewski,V. Ramasesh,Ambrose Slone,Cem Anil,Imanol Schlag,Theo Gutman-Solo,Yuhuai Wu,Behnam Neyshabur,Guy Gur-Ari,Vedant Misra

papers.title: CCTEST: Testing and Repairing Code Completion Systems
papers.authors: Zongjie Li,Chaozheng Wang,Zhibo Liu,Haoxuan Wang,Shuai Wang,Cuiyun Gao
papers.summary: This research proposes CCT EST, a framework to test and repair code completion systems in black-box settings, which features a set of novel mutation strategies, namely program structure-consistent (PSC) mutations, to generate mutated code completion inputs.

papers.title: Automatic Code Documentation Generation Using GPT-3
papers.venue: International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
papers.authors: Junaed Younus Khan,Gias Uddin
papers.summary: Codec is a GPT-3 based model pre-trained on both natural and programming languages that outperforms existing techniques even with basic settings like one-shot learning and achieves an overall BLEU score of 20.6 for six different programming languages.

papers.title: Code as Policies: Language Model Programs for Embodied Control
papers.authors: Jacky Liang,Wenlong Huang,F. Xia,Peng Xu,Karol Hausman,Brian Ichter,Peter R. Florence,Andy Zeng
papers.summary: This paper presents code as policies: a robot-centric formulation of language model generated programs (LMPs) that can represent reactive policies (e.g., impedance controllers), as well as waypoint-based policies (vision-based pick and place, trajectory-based control), demonstrated across multiple real robot platforms.

papers.title: Binding Language Models in Symbolic Languages
papers.authors: Zhoujun Cheng,Tianbao Xie,Peng Shi,Chengzu Li,R.K. Nadkarni,Yushi Hu,Caiming Xiong,Dragomir R. Radev,M. Ostendorf,Luke Zettlemoyer,N. A. Smith,Tao Yu
papers.summary: Binder is a training-free neural-symbolic framework that maps the task input to a program, which allows binding a unified API of language model (LM) functionalities to a programming language (e.g., SQL, Python) to extend its grammar coverage and thus tackle more diverse questions.

papers.title: Language Models are Multilingual Chain-of-Thought Reasoners
papers.authors: Freda Shi,Mirac Suzgun,Markus Freitag,Xuezhi Wang,Suraj Srivats,Soroush Vosoughi,Hyung Won Chung,Yi Tay,Sebastian Ruder,Denny Zhou,Dipanjan Das,Jason Wei
papers.summary: It is shown that the multilingual reasoning abilities of language models extend to other tasks such as commonsense reasoning and word-in-context semantic judgment, and that models have strikingly strong mult bilingual reasoning abilities, even in underrepresented languages such as Bengali and Swahili.

papers.title: FlexType: A Plug-and-Play Framework for Type Inference Models
papers.venue: International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
papers.authors: Sivani Voruganti,Kevin Jesse,Prem Devanbu
papers.summary: This work introduces FlexType, an IDE extension that can be used on both JavaScript and TypeScript to infer types in an interactive or automatic fashion and believes the interactive Visual Studio Code extension is inherently useful in both TypeScript and JavaScript especially when resolving types is taxing for the developer.

papers.title: Challenging BIG-Bench Tasks and Whether Chain-of-Thought Can Solve Them
papers.authors: Mirac Suzgun,Nathan Scales,Nathanael Scharli,Sebastian Gehrmann,Yi Tay,Hyung Won Chung,Aakanksha Chowdhery,Quoc V. Le,E. Chi,Denny Zhou,Jason Wei
papers.summary: It is found that applying chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting to BBH tasks enables PaLM to surpass the average human-rater performance on 10 of the 23 tasks, and Codex to surpass it on 17 of the23 tasks.

papers.title: Soft-Labeled Contrastive Pre-training for Function-level Code Representation
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Xiaonan Li,Daya Guo,Yeyun Gong,Yun Lin,Yelong Shen,Xipeng Qiu,Daxin Jiang,Weizhu Chen,Nan Duan
papers.summary: This paper presents SCodeR, aoft-labeled contrastive pre-training framework with two positive sample construction methods to learn functional-level code representation and shows the effectiveness of the proposed pre- training method.

papers.title: Transformers Learn Shortcuts to Automata
papers.authors: Bingbin Liu,J. Ash,Surbhi Goel,A. Krishnamurthy,Cyril Zhang
papers.summary: The theoretical results completely characterize shortcut solutions, whereby a shallow Transformer with only o(T ) layers can exactly replicate the computation of an automaton on an input sequence of length T .

papers.title: Practical Program Repair in the Era of Large Pre-trained Language Models
papers.authors: Chun Xia,Yuxiang Wei,Lingming Zhang
papers.summary: This study demonstrates that directly applying state-of-the-art PLMs can already substantially outperform all existing APR techniques on all the authors' datasets and shows that PLM-based APR can be further substantially boosted via: increasing the sample size, and incorporating inï¬x template information.

papers.title: Early Experience with Transformer-Based Similarity Analysis for DataRaceBench
papers.venue: International Workshop on Software Correctness for HPC Applications
papers.authors: Winson X. Chen,T. Vanderbruggen,Pei-Hung Lin,C. Liao,M. Emani
papers.summary: The challenges and the solutions when applying transformer-based similarity analysis to new source codes which are unseen by pre-trained transformers are explored, and comparative experiments of different variants of similarity analysis are used to comment on the strengths and limitations of the transformer- based approach and point out future research directions.

Canalli,Rosaline Su,Ruisi Su,Samuel Cahyawijaya,Samuele Garda,Shlok S Deshmukh,Shubhanshu Mishra,Sid Kiblawi,Simon Ott,Sinee Sang-aroonsiri,Srishti Kumar,Stefan Schweter,S. Bharati,T. A. Laud,Th'eo Gigant,Tomoya Kainuma,Wojciech Kusa,Yanis Labrak,Yashasvi Bajaj,Y. Venkatraman,Yifan Xu,Ying Xu,Yun-chao Xu,Z. Tan,Zhongli Xie,Zifan Ye,M. Bras,Younes Belkada,Thomas Wolf
papers.summary: BLOOM is a 176B-parameter open-access language model designed and built thanks to a collaboration of hundreds of researchers and achieves competitive performance on a wide variety of benchmarks, with stronger results after undergoing multitask prompted finetuning.

papers.title: Follow the Wisdom of the Crowd: Effective Text Generation via Minimum Bayes Risk Decoding
papers.authors: Mirac Suzgun,Luke Melas-Kyriazi,Dan Jurafsky
papers.summary: This work presents crowd sampling, a family of decoding methods based on Bayesian risk minimization, to ad-dress this diversity-quality trade-off in open-ended natural-language generation.

papers.title: XTest: A Parallel Multilingual Corpus with Test Cases for Code Translation and Its Evaluation*
papers.venue: 2022 25th International Conference on Computer and Information Technology (ICCIT)
papers.authors: Israt Jahan Rithy,Hasib Hossain Shakil,Niloy Mondal,Fatema Sultana,F. Shah
papers.summary: This paper introduces XTest: A Parallel Multilingual Corpus with Test Cases for Code Translation, which contains parallel programs in 9 languages, Problem statement and test cases and built 30 systems to translate code between some high-resourced and low-resourcing programming languages.

papers.title: JEMMA: An Extensible Java Dataset for ML4Code Applications
papers.authors: Anjan Karmakar,Miltiadis Allamanis,R. Robbes
papers.summary: JEMMA is introduced, which is a largescale, diverse, and high-quality dataset targeted at ML4Code applications, and becomes a workbench that researchers can use to experiment with novel representations and tasks operating on source code.

papers.title: Dialog2API: Task-Oriented Dialogue with API Description and Example Programs
papers.authors: Raphael Shu,Elman Mansimov,Tamer Alkhouli,Nikolaos Pappas,Salvatore Romeo,Arshit Gupta,Saab Mansour,Yi Zhang,D. Roth
papers.summary: An approach tailored for the Dialog2API, where the dialogue states are represented by a stack of programs, with most recently mentioned program on the top of the stack, is proposed.

papers.title: Experiences from Using Code Explanations Generated by Large Language Models in a Web Software Development E-Book
papers.venue: Proceedings of the 54th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education V. 1
papers.authors: S. MacNeil,Andrew Tran,Arto Hellas,Joanne Kim,Sami Sarsa,Paul Denny,Seth Bernstein,Juho Leinonen
papers.summary: The results show that all explanation types were viewed by students and that the majority of students perceived the code explanations as helpful to them, however, student engagement varied by code snippet complexity, explanation type, and code snippet length.

papers.title: Programming Is Hard - Or at Least It Used to Be: Educational Opportunities and Challenges of AI Code Generation
papers.venue: Proceedings of the 54th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education V. 1
papers.authors: Brett A. Becker,Paul Denny,James Finnie-Ansley,Andrew Luxton-Reilly,J. Prather,E. Santos
papers.summary: It is argued that the community needs to act quickly in deciding what possible opportunities can and should be leveraged and how, while also working on overcoming otherwise mitigating the possible challenges.

papers.title: My AI Wants to Know if This Will Be on the Exam: Testing OpenAIâs Codex on CS2 Programming Exercises
papers.venue: IFAC Symposium on Advances in Control Education
papers.authors: James Finnie-Ansley,Paul Denny,Andrew Luxton-Reilly,E. Santos,J. Prather,Brett A. Becker
papers.summary: This paper presents results detailing how Codex performs on more advanced CS2 exam questions taken from past exams, and compares these results to those of students who took the same exams under normal conditions, demonstrating that Codex outscores most students.

papers.title: FLAME: A small language model for spreadsheet formulas
papers.authors: Harshit Joshi,Abishai Ebenezer,J. Cambronero,Sumit Gulwani,Aditya Kanade,Vu Le,Ivan Radivcek,Gust Verbruggen
papers.summary: This work presents FLAME, a T5-based model trained on Excel formulas that leverages domain insights to achieve competitive performance with a substantially smaller model (60M parameters) and two orders of magnitude less training data.

papers.title: CrossCodeBench: Benchmarking Cross-Task Generalization of Source Code Models
papers.authors: Changan Niu,Chuanyi Li,Vincent Ng,Bin Luo
papers.summary: A large-scale benchmark that includes 216 existing code-related tasks is proposed and it is demonstrated that the cross-task generalization of models can be largely improved by in-context learning methods such as few-shot learning and learning from task instructions, which shows the promising prospects of conducting cross- task learning research on this benchmark.

papers.title: The Impact of AI on Developer Productivity: Evidence from GitHub Copilot
papers.authors: Sida Peng,Eirini Kalliamvakou,Peter Cihon,Mert Demirer
papers.summary: Observed heterogenous effects show promise for AI pair programmers to help people transition into software development careers.

papers.title: Studying the effect of AI Code Generators on Supporting Novice Learners in Introductory Programming
papers.authors: Majeed Kazemitabaar,J. Chow,Carl Ka To Ma,B. Ericson,David Weintrop,Tovi Grossman
papers.summary: Using OpenAI Codex significantly increased code-authoring performance while not decreasing performance on manual code-modification tasks, and learners with access to Codex during the training phase performed slightly better on the evaluation post-tests conducted one week later, although this difference did not reach statistical significance.

papers.title: Complex QA and language models hybrid architectures, Survey
papers.authors: Xavier Daull,P. Bellot,Emmanuel Bruno,Vincent Martin,Elisabeth Murisasco
papers.summary: Current solutions and promising strategies are reviewed, using elements such as hybrid LLM architectures, human-in-the-loop reinforcement learning, prompting adaptation, neuro-symbolic and structured knowledge grounding, program synthesis, and others, and an overview of the current research and trends in the area of complex QA.

papers.title: Learning Deep Semantics for Test Completion
papers.authors: Pengyu Nie,Rahul Banerjee,Junyi Jessy Li,R. Mooney,MiloÅ¡ GligoriÄ
papers.summary: This work formalizes the novel task of test completion to automatically complete the next statement in a test method based on the context of prior statements and the code under test, and develops TeCo -- a deep learning model using code semantics for test completion.

papers.title: EvoPrompting: Language Models for Code-Level Neural Architecture Search
papers.authors: Angelica Chen,David Dohan,David R. So
papers.summary: EvoPrompting is successful at designing accurate and efficient neural network architectures across a variety of machine learning tasks, while also being general enough for easy adaptation to other tasks beyond neural network design.

papers.title: A Study of Editor Features in a Creative Coding Classroom
papers.authors: Andrew M. McNutt,Anton Outkine,Ravi Chugh
papers.summary: An experimental editor is implemented and used to teach a sequence of college and high-school creative coding courses to identify opportunities to improve creativity- and novice-focused IDEs and highlight ten-sions in their design.

papers.title: CodeRetriever: Unimodal and Bimodal Contrastive Learning
papers.authors: Xiaonan Li,Yeyun Gong,Yelong Shen,Xipeng Qiu,Hang Zhang,Bolun Yao,Weizhen Qi,Daxin Jiang,Weizhu Chen,Nan Duan
papers.summary: The CodeRetriever model, which combines the unimodal and bimodal contrastive learning to train functionlevel code semantic representations, specifically for the code search task, achieves the new state-ofthe-art performance with significant improvement over existing code pre-trained models.

papers.title: Antecedent Predictions Are More Important Than You Think: An Effective Method for Tree-Based Code Generation
papers.authors: Yihong Dong,Ge Li,Zhi Jin
papers.summary: This paper designs an AST-to-Vector (AST2Vec) method, that maps AST node positions to two-dimensional vectors, to model the position information of AST nodes, and implements and trains an Antecedent Prioritized Tree-based code generation model called APT, which improves the performance of existing Seq2Tree methods.

papers.title: ExploitGen: Template-augmented exploit code generation based on CodeBERT
papers.authors: Guang Yang,Yu Zhou,Xiang Chen,Xiangyu Zhang,Tingting Han,Taolue Chen

papers.title: NL2CMD: An Updated Workflow for Natural Language to Bash Commands Translation
papers.authors: Quchen Fu,Zhongwei Teng,Marco Georgaklis,Jules White,Douglas,C. Schmidt
papers.summary: A state-of-the-art translation model used to generate Bash Commands from the corresponding English text is described and a new NL2CMD dataset is introduced that is automatically generated, involves minimal human intervention, and is over six times larger than prior datasets.

papers.title: Do Users Write More Insecure Code with AI Assistants?
papers.authors: Neil Perry,Megha Srivastava,Deepak Kumar,D. Boneh

papers.title: ProgramTransformer: A tool for generating semantically equivalent transformed programs
papers.authors: Md Rafiqul Islam Rabin,Mohammad Amin Alipour

papers.title: On the Reliability and Explainability of Automated Code Generation Approaches
papers.authors: Yue Liu,C. Tantithamthavorn,Yonghui Liu,Li Li
papers.summary: A thorough empirical study of five code generation models on four representative code generation datasets to assess the limits and capabilities of automatic code generation approaches and reveals that state-of-the-art approaches suffer from severe data duplication and input insensitivity, which are subtle issues with significant implications.

papers.title: Do Machine Learning Models Produce TypeScript Types that Type Check?
papers.authors: Ming-Ho Yee,Arjun Guha
papers.summary: It is argued that accuracy can be misleading, and this paper presents TypeWeaver, a TypeScript type migration tool that can be used with an arbitrary type prediction model and evaluates it with three models from the literature.

papers.title: Can NMT Understand Me? Towards Perturbation-based Evaluation of NMT Models for Code Generation
papers.venue: 2022 IEEE/ACM 1st International Workshop on Natural Language-Based Software Engineering (NLBSE)
papers.authors: Pietro Liguori,Cristina Improta,S. D. Vivo,R. Natella,B. Cukic,Domenico Cotroneo
papers.summary: This work identifies a set of perturbations and metrics tailored for the robustness assessment of NMT models, and presents a preliminary experimental evaluation, showing what type of perturbedations affect the model the most and deriving useful insights for future directions.

papers.title: Toward General Design Principles for Generative AI Applications
papers.authors: Justin D. Weisz,Michael J. Muller,Jessica He,Stephanie Houde

papers.title: On the Effectiveness of Pretrained Models for API Learning
papers.venue: IEEE International Conference on Program Comprehension
papers.authors: M. Hadi,Imam Nur Bani Yusuf,Ferdian Thung,K. Luong,Lingxiao Jiang,F. Fard,David Lo
papers.summary: This work uses a dataset that contains 7 million annotations collected from GitHub to evaluate the effectiveness of recent Pre-trained Transformer based Models (PTMs) for the API learning task and identifies two different tokenization approaches that can contribute to a significant boost in PTMs' performance for theAPI sequence generation task.

papers.title: Optimal Neural Program Synthesis from Multimodal Specifications
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Xi Ye,Qiaochu Chen,IÅil Dillig,Greg Durrett
papers.summary: The experimental results on a multimodal synthesis dataset show that the proposed optimal neural synthesis approach substantially outperforms prior state-of-the-art techniques in terms of accuracy %, finds model-optimal programs more frequently, and explores fewer states during search.

papers.title: Conversational Automated Program Repair
papers.authors: Chun Xia,Lingming Zhang

papers.title: Large Language Models Can Be Easily Distracted by Irrelevant Context
papers.authors: Freda Shi,Xinyun Chen,Kanishka Misra,Nathan Scales,David Dohan,E. Chi,Nathanael Scharli,Denny Zhou
papers.summary: This work investigates the distractibility of large language models, i.e., how the model problem-solving accuracy can be influenced by irrelevant context, and introduces Grade-School Math with Irrelevant Context (GSM-IC), an arithmetic reasoning dataset with irrelevant information in the problem description.

papers.title: The Effectiveness of Transformer Models for Analyzing Low-Level Programs
papers.authors: Zifan Carl,William S. Moses
papers.summary: It is shown that transformer models can translate C to LLVM-IR with high accuracy, by training on a parallel corpus of functions extract from 1 million compilable, open-sourced C programs (AnghaBench) and its corresponding LL VM-IR after compiling with Clang.

papers.title: Learning to Represent Programs with Heterogeneous Graphs
papers.venue: IEEE International Conference on Program Comprehension
papers.authors: Wenhan Wang,Kechi Zhang,Ge Li,Zhi Jin
papers.summary: This paper proposes the heterogeneous program graph (HPG), which provides the types of the nodes and the edges explicitly, and employs the heterogeneity transformer (HGT) architecture to generate representations based on HPG, considering the type of information during processing.

papers.title: Static Prediction of Runtime Errors by Learning to Execute Programs with External Resource Descriptions
papers.authors: David Bieber,Rishab Goel,Daniel Zheng,H. Larochelle,Daniel Tarlow
papers.summary: Surprisingly, it is shown that the model can also predict the location of the error, despite being trained only on labels indicating the presence/absence and kind of error.

papers.title: A Survey of Deep Learning Models for Structural Code Understanding
papers.authors: Ruoting Wu,Yu-xin Zhang,Qibiao Peng,Liang Chen,Zibin Zheng
papers.summary: This survey presents a comprehensive overview of the structures formed from code data, categorizing the models for understanding code in recent years into two groups: sequence-based and graph-based models, and makes some suggestions for future research in structural code understanding field.

papers.title: Learning to Represent Programs with Code Hierarchies
papers.authors: Minh Nguyen,Nghi D. Q. Bui
papers.summary: A method for representing code as a hierarchy ( Code Hierarchy), in which different code components are represented separately at various levels of granular- ity, and a novel pretraining objective called Miss- ing Subtree Prediction to complement this method.

papers.title: Probing Semantic Grounding in Language Models of Code with Representational Similarity Analysis
papers.venue: International Conference on Advanced Data Mining and Applications
papers.authors: Shounak Naik,Rajaswa Patil,Swati Agarwal,V. Baths
papers.summary: This paper probes representations from the CodeBERT model for semantic grounding by using the data from the IBM CodeNet dataset, and shows that using bimodalinputs over unimodal inputs gives better semantic grounding and sample eï¬ciency during semantic ï¬ne-tuning.

papers.title: Are Transformers All That Karel Needs?
papers.authors: Abhay Garg,Anand Sriraman,Kunal Pagarey,S. Karande
papers.summary: By changing the base architecture to a transformer based one, speciï¬cally GPT2, this work is able to apply simple execution guidance on top to achieve a generalization accurary of 89.64%, which is within 2.36 percentage points of the current state-of-the-art on Karel which uses ensembling.

papers.title: Figuring out Figures: Using Textual References to Caption Scientific Figures
papers.authors: Stanley Cao,Kevin Liu
papers.summary: This work uses the S CI C AP datasets curated by Hsu et al. and uses a variant of a CLIP+GPT-2 encoder-decoder model with cross-attention to generate captions conditioned on the image, and uses SciBERT to encode the textual metadata and uses this encoding alongside the figure embedding.

papers.title: Extracting Meaningful Attention on Source Code: An Empirical Study of Developer and Neural Model Code Exploration
papers.authors: Matteo Paltenghi,Rahul Pandita,Austin Z. Henley,Albert Ziegler
papers.summary: This work empirically evaluates attention-agnostic heuris-tics and ten attention-based post processing approaches of the attention signal against the ground truth of developers exploring code, including the novel concept of follow-up attention which exhibits the highest agreement.

papers.title: Latent Execution for Neural Program Synthesis

papers.title: Programming and execution models for next generation code intelligence systems (keynote)
papers.authors: M. Mezini

papers.title: An Empirical Cybersecurity Evaluation of GitHub Copilot's Code Contributions
